description.narrative: Reducing Unintended Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) and Mercury Releases from the Health Sector in Africa.

activity-description.narrative: In collaboration with the Ministry of Health and Ghana Health services the Project seeks to put in place a National Waste Management plan and select and train the following health centres; the Eastern Regional Hospital, Cape Coast Teaching Hospital (cluster treatment facility); Keta Municipal Health

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative:
1) Non-incineration and Mercury-free technologies introduced in African countries. Affordable non-incineration technologies available in the African region. 2) UPOPs releases from the health sector reduced or avoided
3) Mercury releases from the health sector reduced 4) Country capacity built to effectively phase out and reduce releases of POPs
5) Mid-term evaluation criteria and formula for the allocation of technologies among countries available 6) A teams of 4 national experts (16 in total for the four countries) trained at regional level 7) Number of national HCWM strategies, policies, action plans as well as number of drafts for HCWM related standards and guidelines available. 8) Number of National Action Plans for project implementation available 9)Number of Non-incineration HCWM systems and Hg free devices procured. 10) Number of HCWM systems installed and Hg-free devices distributed 11) Number of project HCFs that have introduced BEP. 12) Number of project HCFs that have introduced BEP. Number of HCF staff trained in BEP & BAT. Number of project HCFs that have operational BAT. Number of project HCFs that have recycling programmes in place. No. of project countries that have storage sites for phase-out Hg-containing devices. Number of Mercury-free project HCFs. Number of institutions that offer HCWM training/certificate courses. 13) Evaluation report (including recommendations for each project country and HCF) available. Number of HCWM systems and Hg free devices procured 14) Number of HCFs supported in addition to the initial set of HCFs. Number of Mercury-free project HCFs in addition to the initial set. 15) Number of people trained in addition to the initial set of trained HCF personnel. List of environment and health conferences in the region 16) Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

comment.narrative:
1) In 2012, there were approximately 115 non-incineration HCW technologies installed throughout Africa. In the project countries, 3 working hydroclaves have been installed in Ghana (April 2014). Affordable non-incineration technologies are not available to African HCFs 2) UPOPs baseline: Ghana: 19.8 g-TEQ/yr (pre-selected hospitals) Mercury baseline: Ghana: 8.2 kg/yr (pre-selected hospitals)
3) The regulatory, policy framework not current, national implementation plan not operational and No standard exist in medical waste management Ghana. 4) Evaluation criteria and allocation of technologies among project countries not in place. Some knowledge on Mercury and UPOPs releases from the health sector built during the PPG phase.
5) In each of the project countries the baseline pertaining to the HCWM policy and regulatory framework is different. For Ghana the situation is summarized on page 20 in the section “National Policy regulatory and legal Framework on HCWM in Ghana” Draft National Action Plans for project implementation available. Pre-selection of HCFs has already taken place. 6) Three (3) BAT in 3 pre-selected HCFs and none (0) BEP in place at most of the model HCFs. No recycling programmes in place at any of the HCFs. No storage sites for Mercury or Medical devices containing Mercury available in any of the project countries. In Ghana, some project HCFs already uses some Mercury-free medical devices, but none of the pre-selected HCFs is Mercury-free. In Ghana, training programme for waste management exists, but training programmes for HCWM need to be established/improved

1. 5 autoclaves installed and operational. 2. National modular course on health care waste management developed.
3. Project mid-term evaluation conducted.

1. 5 JSD 250l autoclaves were installed in 3 health care facilities (two for Cape Coast Teaching Hospital, two for Eastern Regional Hospital and one for Tebgi Health Center). The provision of the autoclave treatment technologies and the training provided to health care staff (350 people) in the 5 pilot facilities has contributed to building national capacity to implement best techniques in the management of healthcare waste to eliminate the emission of Unintended Persistent Organic Pollutants like dioxins and furans into the environment, as required by the Stockholm Convention. In the long run, it will contribute to improvement in healthcare delivery which will reduce the exposure to infections on patients, health staff and nearby communities.
2. A national modular course for health care waste management has been established at the Accra School of Hygiene. The objective is to create a system to provide capacity building opportunities for healthcare waste managers and practitioners. 26 trainees ranging from health care workers, environmental health officers and consultants from civil society were trained in 2018 to contribute to already existing capacity in health facilities to manage healthcare waste in an environmentally sound manner.
3. The Project Mid-Term Evaluation was conducted. Its findings are being taken into consideration in the planning of the second phase of the project, starting in 2020.

1)Number of Ministries and Agencies engaged for the finalization of the Policy and Guideline. 2)Number of Policy and Guidelines printed
3) Number of policy dissemination meetings held 4) Number of recycling companies engaged
5) Number of temporary storages constructed for Ghana as interim storage for mercury-containing devices 6) Quantities of mercury-containing devices collected and stored 7) Number of new facilities selected for the second phase 8) Number of new health facilities attached to the first phase facilities to operate a cluster system 9)Number of additional mercury-free devices procured and exchanged with mercury-containing ones 10) Number of trainings conducted for health staff and operators on healthcare waste management. 11) Number of lessons learnt and best practices documented; 12) Number of abstracts submitted for participation in environmental conferences in the Africa region

1. HCWM policy and guidelines disseminated 2. One autoclave installed.
3. 50 HCF staff of the additional HCFs trained in BEP/BAT
